Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Hand-delivering a high-value or sensitive package directly to the recipient and verifying their identity
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I stood at the apartment door, clutching the small, heavy box marked “Confidential—Recipient Only.” My job as a delivery person demanded that I hand this package directly to the addressee and verify their ID, no exceptions. The company trusted me with high-value deliveries because I never cut corners. But as I waited, my phone buzzed with messages from friends already in Mecca, their photos and prayers filling our group chat. This was the year I’d finally saved enough for Hajj, a duty I’d dreamed of fulfilling since childhood. My family and community expected me to go, and I felt the weight of their hopes. Yet, my supervisor had just called, reminding me that any missed or delayed delivery could cost me my job—and the savings I’d worked so hard to build. The recipient was running late, and every minute I waited, I felt the tension between my commitment to my work and my longing to answer the call to pilgrimage. My heart pounded as I stared at the package, torn between two worlds, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait.
